definitions.definition: to mix with a liquid and become part of it

examples.text: Heat gently until the sugar dissolves.
The aspirin hasn't dissolved completely yet.

definitions.definition: to make a solid become part of a liquid
to officially end a marriage, business agreement or parliament

examples.text: The election was announced and parliament was dissolved.
The civilian government was effectively dissolved.
Their marriage was formally dissolved last year.

definitions.definition: to disappear; to make something disappear

examples.text: When the ambulance had gone, the crowd dissolved.
The lights in the windows faded and the house dissolved into darkness again.
His calm response dissolved her anger.

definitions.definition: to suddenly start laughing, crying, etc.

examples.text: When the teacher looked up, the children dissolved into giggles.
Every time she heard his name, she dissolved into tears.

definitions.definition: to remove or destroy something, especially by a chemical process; to be destroyed in this way

examples.text: a new detergent that dissolves stains
All the original calcium had dissolved away.
The limestone has simply dissolved away.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (also in the sense ‘break down into component parts’): from Latin dissolvere, from dis- ‘apart’ + solvere ‘loosen or solve’.
